title: Business & Finance
text:
The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge rose 6.8% in June from the year before, the sharpest rise since January 1982. Meanwhile wages and benefits rose 5.1% in the second quarter from a year earlier.

---

Exxon, Chevron and Shell, the three largest Western oil companies, banked a record $46 billion in collective profits in the second quarter.

---

Procter & Gamble is predicting the slowest sales growth in years as consumer belt-tightening is beginning to hit household staples.

---

The FAA has signed off on a Boeing plan aimed at addressing problems with the 787 Dreamliner, a major step before the company restarts deliveries of the aircraft.

---

Ernst & Young's effort to split its businesses has been slowed by a change in its U.S. leadership, as well as complications over its debts.

---

China Evergrande sketched out the first contours of a long-awaited restructuring plan.

(END)

Major stock indexes rose Friday to end their best month since 2020, clawing back some of their losses from a dismal first half. The S&P 500 gained 9.1% in July, while the Dow rose 6.7%. The Nasdaq climbed 12% for the month.
